text: Hey Steven are you using a drag and drop template or a coded template? CC: <@U22PKFRU5> do you know who might be a good person to loop in here with Shay being out?

<@UJL4N3WN8> Why would you NOT want HubSpot to inline css in email? btw you have control over your own css being inlined, so you can do media queries, you just use 2 style tags, one with the data attribute HS uses to inline
Actually it introduces it's own drag and drop CSS which can take precedence over my CSS
As for why I don't want inlining, it's because I'm a professional email developer and I know what I'm doing.
I don’t mean offense, but if you’re using a drag n drop template, of course it will
you should use a coded template if you want full control
I don't understand why. I simply want it to drag the exact code I wrote in the module in the order I want it.
I understand with columns etc but would be nice to turn those off
Except the client then loses control when building new templates.
if you turned it off that would completely defeat the purpose of the drag n drop template builder
that drag n drop area is not meant for the marketers
Would be a nice feature request to simply be able to drag in modules and change the order they appear in.
yes, that’s why that feature is in beta
Like Marketo
like HubSpot’s drag n drop email editor
Yeah
It's real close! but for now I'll recode and take advantage of extending layout and macros :slightly_smiling_face:
sounds honestly like building 1 module that contains the majority of the email is more the route you want to go for now
that way you can give them drag n drop
What? No way! That's a crazy way to do things.
not really, because you’ll give your customers the ability to drag n drop and choose what types of “blocks” they want and where
I like to break things up into content, one or two column buttons, data table, quotations etc
right you’d do that
you still get all of those benefits
Yeah but the issue is HubSpot adds all their crap to the HTML
I can't disable that
So we easily hit the 102Kb Gmail limit
you wouldn’t need to worry about it because you’d use a coded template with 1 custom module in it
My template comes in at 80Kb
Like I said, I'm happy to go coded, it just means the client will need me to build new templates based on the modules I've created.
So if they want a quotation module to come after some content, I need to copy and re-paste that block in the coded template.
Rather than have them drag it in the template builder
I don’t think you’re understanding me when I say build a coded template with 1 custom module that does it all.
<https://spin.d.pr/ZFCJtd+>
What trickery is this?
I clearly didn't understand you!
It’s a custom module, you just create a field group and set it to repeatable.
then you can add a choice field to your field group for picking which type of content it is

“quotation” “social buttons” “fw image”
“2 up cards” etc
Damn that's nice! Absolutely no one has written about that approach

That's awesome, using a repeater block hadn't occurred to me. I created a set of custom modules at one point that they could drag and drop to create branded templates but this would have been cool - next time!
What would the coding of that module look like?

basically for the repeatable areas you for loop through them.

If you click copy snippet after creating this structure in your module’s fields, it will give you the HubL code to start(you can obviously modify it to fit your needs, it’s just a good starting point)
But I still get to manage the structure of the content though?
Ah yes I see, just copy the for loop and the field value

and <@UBUNBSM24> hopefully you won’t need to do this next time. HubSpot’s been working on bringing the ability to template emails that will work in the new email DnD editor <#CES6JU0RY|drag-drop-email-beta>
<@U7SL518D6> I looked into that briefly (although I keep meaning to play around with it more), but how much will we be able to customise the design for those modules?
if you open up that new beta email builder, click the “more” button, you’ll see your existing email modules are already in there
Good enough apparently, let me at it!
that might give you an idea of the control you have
Awesome, will do! :slightly_smiling_face:
What 'more' button btw?
Found it!

until they add the templating capability though Steve you don’t have full control, and you can’t create templates that are compatible with that builder.

You can create modules however, and you can create emails and save those emails to be duplicated(essentially as if they are templates)
Yeah I just realised that :S
It's nearly there!
As I keep saying though that templating capability is what they are working on now
Ok I got this now. Again, thanks for your patience Jon
no prob.
I've had to run into this with eyes wide shut
yea it can be hard diving into a completely foreign email service provider - they all have their own little quirks or ways of doing things
Tell me about it! This is looking very positive though. If we can build our own templates, use extends/macros and not have any cruft added, then bingo!

The part that also makes HS possibly a little harder is -if you’re an email specialist and don’t do the CMS side of it much, then you wouldn’t know most of the functionality that’s available for websites is available in emails too
True, although using Twig has helped me with hubl
Oh and the option to totally switch off inlining. Really don't need it these days if you're a competent email developer.
there are still benefits to it though that outweigh choosing not to doit
Not really if you know what you're doing. It just adds uneccessary weight to the email.
inlining actually does the opposite of adding weight
How do you work that out?
you’re removing style tags, and all css selectors, for complicated emails that’s a lot of code saved
that you’re not sending down the pipe
Um, as opposed to this `webkit-text-size-adjust:100%; -ms-text-size-adjust:100%; mso-table-lspace:0pt; mso-table-rspace:0pt` in every single table?
I just need a class and a font declaration in a `<td>` and I'm set
Ah I see what you mean, no I don't use dozens of style tags. Classes handle most of that.

I didn’st say you’d use dozens of style tags, I was just meaning the 1 style tag
you are right there that repeated code is bad. but really the main reason to care about it

is whether the people you are sending to can receive it and have it not look broken. That falls under the same area as web dev in general, always design/develop for your audience not the world as a whole
Which is why I have been using Litmus for the last 4 years
Like I said, email development is my profession
absolutely, litmus is fabulous recommend it to everyone
It used to be web development but a long hiatus meant the web was moving too fast!
HubSpot actually uses litmus for it’s email testing btw
Hell yeah, or Email on Acid
It's a popular 3rd party add-in but I didn't know it was baked into HS...
That's interesting!
yea they have some kinda direct integration, so when you use the email test button to get screenshots that’s what it’s actually doing
is just sending it to Litmus and Litmus sends back screengrabs. Not as useful as using in litmus directly but great for if you can’t justify the price of litmus in your billing to clients
(usually though we just factor the cost of litmus into our pricing and take off an hour or 2 of dev time(because it totally saves you 2-4 hours of troubleshooting sometimes)
Hell yeah, I code emails in Builder so I get live updates and have inlining switched off.
I like to keep my code as light and portable as possible while keeping compatibility with Outlook, Samsung Mail, Outlook iOS and other outliers.

I can tell you’re one of us that when asked “so how long have you been doing email development?” you’re likely to answer “too danm long.”
lol

(that’s how you know an email dev is good lol.)
haha so so true
Every email developer is this person when they test in Litmus -
<https://i.giphy.com/media/xUOwGkoxib4Y9A9T9u/giphy.gif>
And when their code works in Outlook on the first test they be like -
<https://i.giphy.com/media/Ax1JUM9QI942Y/giphy.gif>
haha so true
So do you build emails for clients too?

that and after solving some rediculous outlook bug <https://media.giphy.com/media/iLhlW2bctT1f2/giphy.gif>
<https://media.giphy.com/media/7NWhfa1lEHPqw/giphy.gif>

Yea. I don’t do as much as I used to - used to work at an ad agency and would crank out 3-4 new email designs/templates a week.

Now things are a bit different. My company is a HS and WP development company, and we partner with agencies to build and maintain the sites, and we do get email template work but it’s different
we’re usually making more multi-purpose emails that are less fancy but give the marketers control.

it’s a big change from previously I was doing crazy things like made an email design for a bar, where the majority of the email had a background that was a beer glass(with the text and content overlayed over it) and I made it so that if images were disabled in the email the glass of beer would turn into a pixelated version of the glass of beer, using background color and way too many dang table cells

some thing I’ve really been wanting to get into with email dev is more of the interactive stuff, I know HOW to do the crazy stuff Litmus has done in their emails with interactivity, but clients never have the budget for it.
haha nice!
Yeah interactivity is really reserved for the bigger players. There's smaller things you can do but I don't really class button hovers as interactivity as some do.
I'm more focused on accessibility and good editorial experiences (hence my ranting here!)
hopefully amp for email will kinda change the amount of time it takes to do interactive. I’m mostly positive about amp for email but am not all in on it
yea by interactivity I was meaning stuff like what table tr td, and litmus do in their emails. will try to post a link to an example
<https://www.emailonacid.com/blog/article/email-development/minesweeper-interactive-email-interview-with-camille-and-miah-from-table-tr/>
couldn’t find the archive of the actual email
but basic jist the email is a full working game of minesweeper using CSS and checboxes
and a css based timer
oh and it kept score too
hard to justify to clients - hey can I have an extra like 6 hours to build something rediculous and cool into your email
And the rest once you factor in testing!
I'm not actually that excited about AMP, I think it will die on the vine
yea, I’m less worried actually about it dying off, and more worried about it preventing email clients from actually catching up to modern web standards of support
Clients won't unless web mail dies off
Which it won't
because it’s like “Hey look we have a new SHINY” when everyones like “that’s great but…. why no css animations yet?”
Too many security worries
haha, why can't I just use divs already?
well surprisingly AMP is already supported in many major email providers
Well you can if your audience doesn't use Outlook..
actually you can use divs ….. it’s just really flippin hard (litmus had an article on it)
Some yes
That's right, divs and a ghost table
But it can be a right pain
funny part is I’m like “I want the html elements that come AFTER divs”
for example - 1 really powerful html element for email would be the details and summary elements
they’d make them accessible AND provide new functionality
Oh yes
For now we make do with `role="presentation"`, `h1`, `h2` etc and `alt` tags
Seems frequently lately the `Test in different email clients` has been unavailable / errors out when trying to run a test.
